newsitem.title: CHINA: PRESS DIGEST - HK NEWSPAPER HEADLINES -- AUG 14.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - HK NEWSPAPER HEADLINES -- AUG 14.

text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the Hong Kong press. Reuter has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

-- SOUTH CHINA MORNING POST -- Chief Executive Tung Chee-hwa was set to make his first official trip overseas next month to convince Americans that the Hong Kong way of life and freedom have remained intact.

-- Tycoon Li Ka-shing's Hutchison Whampoa had joined forces with his son's privately held company, Pacific Century, to develop a $5.82 billion site in Tokyo, the largest co-operation venture between father and son to date.

-- HONGKONG STANDARD -- The Securities and Futures Commission had asked several local broking firms to lower debt levels and retire over-exposed clients for fear that the firms could collapse if there was a stock market correction.

-- ECONOMIC TIMES -- Beijing sources said that the Minister of Foreign Economic Co-operation and Trade, Wu Yi, would become Vice-Premier and Foreign Minister at the 15th Party Congress. Premier Li Peng would head the law-making National People's Congress, while his present position would be taken by his deputy, Zhu Rongji. They said President Jiang Zemin had gained total control over personnel arrangements.

-- SING TAO -- Sources close to the Beidaihe meeting of the Chinese Communist Party top leadership said that "anti-bourgeois liberalisation" would not be an issue at the 15th Party Congress. Analysts said it represented a big leap forward in the Communist ideology.

-- APPLE DAILY -- Hong Kong's Independent Commission Against Corruption was investigating a case in which two managers of two top local hotels were suspected of receiving bribes from decoration companies for giving them rennovation projects worth close to $100 million.
-- WEN WEI PO -- A Beijing propaganda official said that the Chinese Communist Party had cleared up the confusion over whether the country's economy was socialist or capitalist.
-- MING PAO -- China's CCTV's planned television series on the Korean War, titled "Resist the US Aggression and Aid Korea", had been dropped for diplomatic reasons. Newsroom (852) 28436441
